metadata.title: W3Schools.com

metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML Elements
An XML document contains XML Elements.
content.html: An XML document contains XML Elements.

content.text: What is an XML Element?
An XML element is everything from (including) the element's start tag to (including) the element's end tag.
content.html: An XML element is everything from (including) the element's start tag to (including) the element's end tag.

content.code_html: <price>29.99</price>

content.text: An element can contain:
content.html: An element can contain:

content.code:
<bookstore>

<book category="children">

<title>Harry Potter</title>
 
<author>J K. Rowling</author>

<year>2005</year>

<price>29.99</price>

</book>

<book category="web">

<title>Learning XML</title>

<author>Erik T. Ray</author>

<year>2003</year>

<price>39.95</price>

</book>

</bookstore>
content.code_html:
<bookstore>
  <book category="children">
    <title>Harry Potter</title>
    <author>J K. Rowling</author>
    <year>2005</year>
    <price>29.99</price>
  </book>
  <book category="web">
    <title>Learning XML</title>
    <author>Erik T. Ray</author>
    <year>2003</year>
    <price>39.95</price>
  </book>
</bookstore>

content.text: In the example above:
content.html: In the example above:

content.text: <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price> have text content because they contain text (like 29.99).
content.html: <title>, <author>, <year>, and <price> have text content because they contain text (like 29.99).

content.text: <bookstore> and <book> have element contents , because they contain elements.
content.html: <bookstore> and <book> have element contents, because they contain elements.

content.text: <book> has an attribute (category="children").
content.html: <book> has an attribute (category="children").

content.text: Empty XML Elements
An element with no content is said to be empty.
content.html: An element with no content is said to be empty.

content.text: In XML, you can indicate an empty element like this:
content.html: In XML, you can indicate an empty element like this:

content.code_html: <element></element>

content.text: You can also use a so called self-closing tag:
content.html: You can also use a so called self-closing tag:

content.code_html: <element />

content.text: The two forms produce identical results in XML software (Readers, Parsers, Browsers).
content.html: The two forms produce identical results in XML software (Readers, Parsers, Browsers).

content.text: Empty elements can have attributes.
content.html: Empty elements can have attributes.

content.text: XML Naming Rules
XML elements must follow these naming rules:
content.html: XML elements must follow these naming rules:

content.text: Any name can be used, no words are reserved (except xml).
content.html: Any name can be used, no words are reserved (except xml).

content.text: Best Naming Practices
Create descriptive names, like this: <person>, <firstname>, <lastname>.
content.html: Create descriptive names, like this: <person>, <firstname>, <lastname>.

content.text: Create short and simple names, like this: <book_title> not like this: <the_title_of_the_book>.
content.html: Create short and simple names, like this: <book_title> not like this: <the_title_of_the_book>.

content.text: Avoid "-". If you name something "first-name", some software may think you want to subtract "name" from "first".
content.html: Avoid "-". If you name something "first-name", some software may think you want to subtract "name" from "first".

content.text: Avoid ".". If you name something "first.name", some software may think that "name" is a property of the object "first".
content.html: Avoid ".". If you name something "first.name", some software may think that "name" is a property of the object "first".

content.text: Avoid ":". Colons are reserved for namespaces (more later).
content.html: Avoid ":". Colons are reserved for namespaces (more later).

content.text: Non-English letters like éòá are perfectly legal in XML, but watch out for problems if your software doesn't support them!
content.html: Non-English letters like éòá are perfectly legal in XML, but watch out for problems if your software doesn't support them!

content.text: Naming Conventions
Some commonly used naming conventions for XML elements:
content.html: Some commonly used naming conventions for XML elements:

content.text: Tip! Choose your naming style, and be consistent about it!
content.html: Tip! Choose your naming style, and be consistent about it!

content.text: XML documents often have a corresponding database. A common practice is to use the naming rules of the database for the XML elements.
content.html: XML documents often have a corresponding database. A common practice is to use the naming rules of the database for the XML elements.

content.text: XML Elements are Extensible
XML elements can be extended to carry more information.
content.html: XML elements can be extended to carry more information.

content.text: Look at the following XML example:
content.html: Look at the following XML example:

content.code_html:
<note>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: Let's imagine that we created an application that extracted the <to>, <from>, and <body> elements from the XML document to produce this output:
content.html: Let's imagine that we created an application that extracted the <to>, <from>, and <body> elements from the XML document to produce this output:

content.text: To: Tove From: Jani
content.html:
To: Tove
From: Jani

content.text: Don't forget me this weekend!
content.html: Don't forget me this weekend!

content.text: Imagine that the author of the XML document added some extra information to it:
content.html: Imagine that the author of the XML document added some extra information to it:

content.code_html:
<note>
  <date>2008-01-10</date>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: Should the application break or crash?
content.html: Should the application break or crash?

content.text: No. The application should still be able to find the <to>, <from>, and <body> elements in the XML document and produce the same output.
content.html: No. The application should still be able to find the <to>, <from>, and <body> elements in the XML document and produce the same output.

content.text: This is one of the beauties of XML. It can be extended without breaking applications.
content.html: This is one of the beauties of XML. It can be extended without breaking applications.
